key.substructure.key.doc.comment: This is a class to help with the conversion between C strings and the Swift [String](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swift/string/) class. One note about the use of signed and unsigned chars. Some C functions make a distinction between a signed char (usually the default - when only the lower 7-bits are significant) and an unsigned char (usually in conjunction with the UTF-8 character encoding scheme). This class has methods to handle both.
key.substructure.key.doc.full_as_xml: CStrings:7Rubicon7CStringCopen class CStringThis is a class to help with the conversion between C strings and the Swift ]]>String]]> class. One note about the use of signed and unsigned chars. Some C functions make a distinction between a signed char (usually the default - when only the lower 7-bits are significant) and an unsigned char (usually in conjunction with the UTF-8 character encoding scheme). This class has methods to handle both.

key.substructure.key.doc.comment:
Initialize this object with the contents of the byte (unsigned char) buffer. The bytes will be interpreted
as a series of characters encoded with the given character encoding.

- Parameters:
  - byteBuffer: The byte buffer.
  - hasNullTerminator: `true` if the buffer includes a `nil` terminating character. Defaults to `false`.
  - encoding: The character encoding used. Defaults to UTF-8.
key.substructure.key.doc.declaration: public init(byteBuffer: UnsafeBufferPointer<UInt8>, hasNullTerminator: Bool = false, encoding: String.Encoding = String.Encoding.utf8)

key.substructure.key.doc.comment:
Initialize this object with the contents of the character (signed char) buffer. The characters will be
interpreted as a series of characters encoded with the given character encoding.

- Parameters:
  - charBuffer: The character buffer.
  - hasNullTerminator: `true` if the buffer includes a `nil` terminating character. Defaults to `false`.
  - encoding: The character encoding used. Defaults to UTF-8.

key.substructure.key.doc.comment: Initializes this object with the contents of the immutable character (signed char) from the given pointer. If length is not given or is less than [zero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/0) then the string MUST be `nil` terminated. If the length is less than [zero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/0) and the string is NOT `nil` terminated then the behavior of this initializer is undefined. - Parameters: - cString: The pointer to the characters. - length: The length of the string. If less than [zero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/0) then the string MUST be `nil` terminated. - encoding: The character encoding used. Defaults to UTF-8.
key.substructure.key.doc.declaration: public init(cString: UnsafePointer<CChar>, length: Int = -1, encoding: String.Encoding = String.Encoding.utf8)

If length is not given or is less than ]]>zero]]> then the string MUST be nil terminated. If the length is less than ]]>zero]]> and the string is NOT nil terminated then the behavior of this initializer is undefined.cStringinThe pointer to the characters.lengthinThe length of the string. If less than ]]>zero]]> then the string MUST be nil terminated.encodinginThe character encoding used. Defaults to UTF-8.

key.substructure.key.annotated_decl: <Declaration>public static func newUtf8BufferOf(length: <Type usr="s:Si">Int</Type>, _ block: (<Type usr="s:7Rubicon11BytePointera">BytePointer</Type>, <Type usr="s:Si">Int</Type>) throws -> <Type usr="s:Si">Int</Type>) -> <Type usr="s:7Rubicon7CStringC">CString</Type>?</Declaration>
key.substructure.key.doc.comment:
Create a new CString and do something with it right away. So, for example, instead of having to do this: 
   let buffer = UnsafeMutablePointer.allocate(capacity: 256)
   defer { buffer.deallocate() }
   guard strerror_r(code, buffer, 255) == 0 else { return "Unknown Error: \(code)" }
   let str = String(utf8String: buffer) ?? "Unknown Error: \(code)"
You can, instead, do this: 
    let str = (CString.newUtf8BufferOf(length: 255) { ((strerror_r(code, $0, $1) == 0) ? strlen($0) : -1) })?.string ?? "Unknown Error: \(code)"
- Parameters: - length: The length of the buffer to create NOT INCLUDING the `nil` terminator. - block: The closure that will get executed. The buffer and it's length, NOT INCLUDING the `nil` terminator, will be passed to the closure. Upon success the closure should return the actual length of the C string in the buffer, NOT INCLUDING, the `nil` terminator. If there was an error then the closure should return -1 to indicate that the buffer does not contain a valid C string. - Returns: An instance of CString or `nil` if -1 was returned from the closure.
key.substructure.key.doc.declaration: public static func newUtf8BufferOf(length: Int, _ block: (BytePointer, Int) throws -> Int) -> CString?

So, for example, instead of having to do this:lengthinThe length of the buffer to create NOT INCLUDING the nil terminator.blockinThe closure that will get executed. The buffer and it’s length, NOT INCLUDING the nil terminator, will be passed to the closure. Upon success the closure should return the actual length of the C string in the buffer, NOT INCLUDING, the nil terminator. If there was an error then the closure should return -1 to indicate that the buffer does not contain a valid C string.An instance of CString or nil if -1 was returned from the closure. let buffer = UnsafeMutablePointer.allocate(capacity: 256) defer { buffer.deallocate() } guard strerror_r(code, buffer, 255) == 0 else { return "Unknown Error: \(code)" } let str = String(utf8String: buffer) ?? "Unknown Error: \(code)" ]]>You can, instead, do this: let str = (CString.newUtf8BufferOf(length: 255) { ((strerror_r(code, $0, $1) == 0) ? strlen($0) : -1) })?.string ?? "Unknown Error: \(code)" ]]>
key.substructure.key.doc.name: newUtf8BufferOf(length:_:)

discussion.Para: The length of the buffer to create NOT INCLUDING the `nil` terminator.

The closure that will get executed. The buffer and it’s length, NOT INCLUDING the `nil` terminator, will be passed to the closure. Upon success the closure should return the actual length of the C string in the buffer, NOT INCLUDING, the `nil` terminator. If there was an error then the closure should return -1 to indicate that the buffer does not contain a valid C string.

key.doc.result_discussion.Para: An instance of CString or `nil` if -1 was returned from the closure.

key.substructure.key.annotated_decl: <Declaration>public static func newCCharBufferOf(length: <Type usr="s:Si">Int</Type>, encoding: <Type usr="s:SS">String</Type>.<Type usr="s:SS10FoundationE8EncodingV">Encoding</Type> = String.Encoding.utf8, _ block: (<Type usr="s:Sp">UnsafeMutablePointer</Type><<Type usr="s:s5CChara">CChar</Type>>, <Type usr="s:Si">Int</Type>) throws -> <Type usr="s:Si">Int</Type>) -> <Type usr="s:7Rubicon7CStringC">CString</Type>?</Declaration>
key.substructure.key.doc.comment:
Create a new CString and do something with it right away. So, for example, instead of having to do this: 
   let buffer = UnsafeMutablePointer.allocate(capacity: 256)
   defer { buffer.deallocate() }
   guard strerror_r(code, buffer, 255) == 0 else { return "Unknown Error: \(code)" }
   let str = String(cString: buffer, encoding: String.Encoding.windowsCP1250) ?? "Unknown Error: \(code)"
You can, instead, do this: 
    let str = (CString.newCCharBufferOf(length: 255, encoding: String.Encoding.windowsCP1250) { ((strerror_r(code, $0, $1) == 0) ? strlen($0) : -1) })?.string ?? "Unknown Error: \(code)"
- Parameters: - length: The length of the buffer to create NOT INCLUDING the `nil` terminator. - encoding: The encoding that the characters are expected to be in. Defaults to UTF-8. - block: The closure that will get executed. The buffer and it's length, NOT INCLUDING the `nil` terminator, will be passed to the closure. Upon success the closure should return the actual length of the C string in the buffer, NOT INCLUDING, the `nil` terminator. If there was an error then the closure should return -1 to indicate that the buffer does not contain a valid C string. - Returns: An instance of CString or `nil` if -1 was returned from the closure.

"Unknown Error: \(code)" ]]>You can, instead, do this: let str = (CString.newCCharBufferOf(length: 255, encoding: String.Encoding.windowsCP1250) { ((strerror_r(code, $0, $1) == 0) ? strlen($0) : -1) })?.string ?? "Unknown Error: \(code)" ]]>
key.substructure.key.doc.name: newCCharBufferOf(length:encoding:_:)

discussion.Para: The length of the buffer to create NOT INCLUDING the `nil` terminator.
The encoding that the characters are expected to be in. Defaults to UTF-8.

The closure that will get executed. The buffer and it’s length, NOT INCLUDING the `nil` terminator, will be passed to the closure. Upon success the closure should return the actual length of the C string in the buffer, NOT INCLUDING, the `nil` terminator. If there was an error then the closure should return -1 to indicate that the buffer does not contain a valid C string.

key.doc.result_discussion.Para: An instance of CString or `nil` if -1 was returned from the closure.

key.substructure.key.parsed_declaration: public static func newCCharBufferOf(length: Int, encoding: String.Encoding = String.Encoding.utf8, _ block: (UnsafeMutablePointer<CChar>, Int) throws -> Int) -> CString?
